questions.text: The type of knot seen in the image is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows the suture material exiting the knot is on the same side as the entry i.e no cross-over is seen. This is seen in a reef knot.

A knot is a fastening made of threads intertwined together or on themselves. Each knot consists of- 2 half-hitches placed in sequential throws. Squaring refers to tightening the knot/half-hitch in a manner that the threads lay flat due to the alternating direction of half-hitches in adjacent layers.

Types of knots:

  1. Granny knot: half-hitch over a half-hitch in the same direction. It has better-holding power than half-hitch
  2. Reef knot: half-hitch followed by a second half-hitch after squaring. 
  3. Triple throw knot: Reef knot with another half-hitch knot for added security. Knots made with prolene sutures require 6-8 throws to prevent slippage.
  4. Surgeon’s knot: Modification of the reef knot with two half-hitches in the first layer.
  5. Slip knot: Modification of either granny/reef knot formed when one end of the thread is kept taut while tightening the knot.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs causes carcinoma bladder?
questions.solution:
Cyclophosphamide (an alkylating agent) causes bladder cancer

The risk of bladder cancer with cyclophosphamide is directly proportional to the duration and intensity of cyclophosphamide treatment. Phosphoramide mustard is the primary mutagenic metabolite that causes bladder cancer in patients exposed to cyclophosphamide.

Painless, gross hematuria is the most common symptom that is indicative of a bladder carcinoma until proven otherwise. 

Depending upon the depth of invasion, bladder carcinoma can be divided into 

  1. Flat, non-invasive carcinoma in situ (CIS)
  2. Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (70% of cases) - does not invade detrusor muscle but can invade lamina propria. 
  3. Muscle-invasive bladder cancer - invades the detrusor muscle.

Diagnosis is by cystourethroscopy (directly visualizing the growth) and biopsy. Management is as follows: 

  1. Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer:
    1. Transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) followed by intravesical chemotherapy with mitomycin C or epirubicin
    2. Immunotherapy with regular intravesical instillations of Bacille Calmette Guerin (BCG) in high-risk tumors.
  2. Muscle invasive bladder cancer: Radical cystectomy along with urinary diversion procedure and lymph node dissection +/- neoadjuvant chemotherapy

Other options:

Option B: Cisplatin is an anticancer drug used to treat testicular cancer. It is associated with an increased risk for acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

Option C: Taxane is an anticancer drug and is the main component in the treatment regimens of metastatic cancers. Taxane's adverse effects are neutropenia and fluid retention (pulmonary edema).

Option D: Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) and is used in the treatment of estrogen-dependent breast cancer. Due to its partial agonistic activity, it is known to increase endometrial cancer in post-menopausal women.

questions.text: The most common site of branchial cyst is ______.

choices.text: Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle
Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle
Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle

questions.solution:
The most common site of a branchial cyst is at the junction of the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle at its anterior border.

The below image shows a large right-sided branchial cyst.

Branchial cyst develops due to the persistence of the cervical sinus. The cervical sinus is formed when the 2nd arch mesoderm overgrows the succeeding arches and overhangs them as shown in the image. The space between the overhanging 2nd pharyngeal arch and the 3rd, 4th, and 6th arches is called the cervical sinus. The cavity of the cervical sinus is lined by ectoderm and normally gets obliterated.

Branchial cysts are usually lined by squamous epithelium and contain thick, turbid fluid full of cholesterol crystals. It is fluctuant and may transilluminate when it contains clear fluid.

A branchial fistula may be acquired or congenital. The congenital fistula is seen at the junction of the middle and lower third of the sternomastoid (option B). An acquired fistula is usually seen in cases of incomplete surgery for the branchial cyst or spontaneous rupture, and it is seen at the same site as the cyst.

questions.text: Dohlman’s  procedure is  for:
questions.solution:
Dohlman’s procedure is done for Zenker’s diverticulum.

It is a transoral endoscopic approach, that ablates the septum between the diverticulum and the cervical esophagus. It can be used for diverticula between 2 and 5 cm in size.

Other options:

Option A: Meckel’s diverticulum is a remnant of the vitellointestinal duct and is treated by surgical resection.

Option C: Bochadlek’s hernia is a congenital posterolateral defect on the left side of the diaphragm due to defective embryological development.

Option D: Menetrier’s disease is a premalignant condition with gross hypertrophy of gastric mucosal folds and is treated with gastrectomy. 

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: Parathyroid gland post surgery  is commonly transferred to:
questions.solution:
The parathyroid is commonly transferred to the brachioradialis muscle post-surgery. This will facilitate easy removal if there is disease recurrence after surgery.

Parathyroidectomy is indicated in:

  1. Symptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism (HPT):  
  2. Asymptomatic primary HPT with:
    • raise in serum calcium >1mg/dl of the normal range
    • >400 mg urinary calcium in 24-hour urine test
    • < -2.5 Z-score of bone mineral density
    • Age <50yr and failed medical treatment 
  3. Severe cases of secondary HPT

Parathyroidectomy is performed in neck hyperextension (semi-Fowler position). The thyroid gland is mobilized, and the parathyroid gland with adenoma is identified and resected. The parathyroid tissue is transplanted to the non-dominant forearm.

Pockets are made in the belly of the brachioradialis muscle, and one to two pieces of parathyroid tissue measuring 1 mm each are placed into each pocket. A total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted. This is a type of heterotopic transplant.

Miami criteria (confirm the absence of another hyperactive parathyroid): A drop of parathyroid hormone intraoperatively, to more than half the maximum value at 10 minutes postresection is considered an adequate resection in a parathyroid adenoma. However, if there is no drop in PTH level, then a multi-gland disease is suspected and the surgery is converted to a bilateral neck exploration.

Complications of parathyroidectomy include:

  1. Persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism
  2. Hypoparathyroidism (presenting as hypocalcemia)
  3. Hungry bone syndrome
  4. Injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve

Related Pearl: Types of transplants

Type  Definition
Orthotopic

Organ implanted in the same anatomic location in the recipient as it was in the donor. Diseased organ is removed. Eg: heart, lung, liver, intestine
Heterotopic

Organ implanted in a different anatomic location. Diseased organ is left in place. Eg: Kidney, pancreas
Auxiliary transplantation Partial tissue from the donor is used which acts as temporary support for the recipient's injured organ, which remains in place. Eg: left lobe of liver
Autotransplant  Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same person. 
Allotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same species. 
Xenotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs in a different species.
Isograft Transfer of organ or tissue within genetically identical individuals. Eg: Identical twins

questions.text: What is the drug used for estrogen dependant breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that is mainly used for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancers in pre-menopausal women.

It exhibits selective agonistic and antagonistic activity for ER receptors (ERα and ERβ):

  • Agonist activity at the uterus, bone, liver, and pituitary
  • Antagonist activity in breast and blood vessels

Uses: 

  • Part of the primary treatment regimen for estrogen receptor-positive (ER+) breast cancers in pre-menopausal women
  • Adjuvant therapy after breast conservative surgery to prevent a recurrence
  • Tamoxifen also is effective (a 40%–50% reduction in tumor incidence) in preventing ER+ breast cancer in women at increased risk.

Adverse effects: 

  • Vasomotor symptoms (hot flashes) and sweating
  • Endometrial cancer
  • Increased risk of thromboembolic events
  • Fatty liver disease

Related Pearl: Hormonal therapy in breast carcinoma given for ER/PR-positive cases

Role:

  • Reduce risk of recurrence
  • Reduce risk of contralateral breast cancer
  • Reduce risk of progression of in situ to invasive carcinoma

  • Arzoxifen

questions.text: The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via:
questions.solution:
The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via the neck and the most common type of goitre approached is the secondary retrosternal goiter.

A goiter is considered to be retrosternal if at least 50% of the thyroid tissue is located intrathoracically. They can be primary or secondary.

  Primary retrosternal goiter Secondary retrosternal goiter
Occurrence 1%  Majority of retrosternal goiters 
Origin

Arise from ectopic thyroid tissue in the chest

No connection with the thyroid tissue in the neck

 Arise from the downward extension of cervical thyroid tissue along the fascial planes of the neck
Blood supply Intrathoracic blood vessels Superior and inferior thyroid arteries

Retrosternal goiter presents with dyspnoea, stridor, and dilated neck veins. Pemberton’s sign (venous congestion of the neck on the raising of hands above the head) is seen.  

Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) of the neck is performed to assess the location of the thyroid. The definitive treatment is surgical excision of the ectopic thyroid.

Other options:

Option B & C: Median sternotomy (via chest) is indicated in:

  • Primary mediastinal goiter
  • Malignant retrosternal goiter
  • Very large retrosternal goiter
  • Recurrence in the mediastinum

questions.text: An intern placed an intercostal drainage tube in a patient. Which of the following steps is incorrect?

choices.text: Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid axillary line to place the tube
Inserted tube along the lower border of upper rib
Directed tube posteriorly to prevent injury

questions.solution:
An intercostal tube (ICD) is placed along the upper border of the lower rib at the 5th intercostal space (ICS) to prevent damage to the neurovascular bundle. Hence, option B is incorrect.

Chest tube insertion (thoracostomy) is indicated in pneumothorax, hemothorax, chylothorax, and pleural effusion in order to drain air/fluid from the pleural space.

The triangle of safety, usually in the 5th intercostal space, is the safest site for chest tube insertion, it is bound by:

  1. anterior to the midaxillary line
  2. above the horizontal line marked by the level of the nipple
  3. below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle

Contraindications include pulmonary adhesions, pulmonary trauma, coagulopathy, and diaphragmatic hernia.

Complications of this procedure:

  1. Infection at the site of insertion
  2. Unintentional injury to the lung - hemothorax
  3. Intercostal nerve/ vessel injury
  4. Subcutaneous hematoma/ emphysema

questions.text: What is the size of the given blade used for incision and drainage of a superficial abscess?
questions.solution:
The size of the surgical blade shown is the 11-size blade (stab knife) that has a triangular shape with an oblique edge and a sharp-pointed tip.

Uses:

  • Incision and drainage (I & D) of an abscess
  • Insertion of drains and arteriotomy.

Other options:

Option A: The 10-size blade is used for skin incisions. It has a curved cutting edge that tapers to a pointed tip.

Option C: The 22-size blade is often used for abdominal incisions. It has a flat, unsharpened back edge and a curved front cutting edge.

Option D: The 15-size blade is used for minor surgical procedures (lipoma excision) and precise skin incisions. It is a smaller blade with a small cutting edge.

questions.text: In a blast injury, which of the following organs is least vulnerable to the blast wave?
questions.solution:
In a blast injury, the liver is the least vulnerable to blast wave (primary blast) injury.

Blast injury is a complex type of physical trauma resulting from direct or indirect exposure to an explosion. Primary blast injuries result from the rapid overpressure or shock waves produced by an explosion. These injuries result from the dramatic changes in barometric pressure projecting outwards from the point of detonation. They predominantly cause damage to air-filled hollow organs of the body from rapid pressure change (barotrauma). This includes the middle ear, lungs, and GIT.

The most sensitive and most frequently injured hollow organs are the tympanic membranes > lungs. Blast damage to the lungs is the most common cause of life-threatening injury following an explosion.

Solid organs are the most resistant to blast injuries as the parenchymal disruption requires very high levels of overpressure. 

Classification of blast injuries:

Classification Explanation Injury type Examples
Primary blast Due to air pressure from the blast Shockwave (overpressure) Tympanic membrane injury, blast lung, intestinal blast injury
Secondary blast Fragments from the blast, following a detonation Penetrating/fragmentation All penetrating injuries
Tertiary blast Gross movements of persons, objects, or infrastructure by the blast wind Blunt trauma Blunt and crush injuries. Traumatic amputation.
Quaternary blast Miscellaneous causes Exposure to explosive products or toxic substances Burns, inhalation injury
Quinary blast The intentional addition of biological or radioactive material to the explosive device Environmental contaminants Radiation sickness, infection.

questions.text: A man presents with a slowly progressive swelling over the past 1 and 1/2 years. On examination, it has a variable consistency and appears as shown in the image. What is the probable cause?
questions.solution:
A slowly progressive swelling, with a variable consistency, lifting the ear lobe, is suggestive of pleomorphic adenoma of the parotid gland.

Pleomorphic adenoma, the most common benign salivary gland tumor, primarily affects the parotid gland, particularly its superficial lobe. It is also referred to as a mixed tumor due to its combination of epithelial and mesenchymal components. This tumor most commonly occurs in females around the age of 40.

Clinical features:

  • Painless, slow-growing swelling
  • Lobulated, firm, variable in consistency
  • Lifts the earlobe
  • No facial nerve involvement
  • Curtain sign positive - cannot be moved above the zygomatic bone.
  • In case of deep lobe involvement, tonsils, and faucial pillars will be pushed medially.
  • Features of malignancy - a sudden increase in size, ulceration of the overlying skin, facial nerve palsy (involvement of facial nerve), painful swelling, and restriction of jaw movements.

Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is the investigation of choice in diagnosing pleomorphic adenoma. Open biopsy is contraindicated due to the chances of injury to the facial nerve.

All tumors of the superficial lobe of the parotid gland should be managed by superficial parotidectomy. Radical parotidectomy is performed for malignant pleomorphic adenoma.

Other options:

Option A: Adamantinoma is a low-grade malignant tumor that usually presents with pre-tibial pain and swelling since it most commonly affects the tibial diaphysis.

Option B:  Dermoid cysts present as firm painless subcutaneous nodules and are of 4 types:

  1. Sequestration dermoid - sequestration of epithelium during embryological development.
  2. Tubulodermoid - accumulation of secretions from ectodermal tube/duct
  3. Implantation dermoid - implantation of the epidermis due to trauma
  4. Teratomatous dermoid - having all 3 germ layers (ecto, meso, and endoderm)

Option D: Sebaceous cysts are retention cysts of the sebaceous glands that present as smooth, non-tender, non-transillumination swelling with a punctum (in 70% of the patients). 

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

Related Pearl: Salivary gland tumors and their frequency

  • Most (90%) of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant, whereas parotid gland tumors (90%) are benign.
  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the parotid.  It is a benign tumor.

questions.text: What is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The image shows a dark-colored summit over a swelling, usually seen in a sebaceous cyst.

Sebaceous cysts are the retention cysts of the sebaceous gland that are usually present on the face, scalp, or scrotum. They contain yellowish-white cheesy material with fat and epithelium.

Clinical features: 

  • The swelling is painless, soft, and freely mobile.
  • Though non-transilluminating, they are Paget's test positive (fluctuant).
  • Punctum is seen in 70% of the patients with sebaceous cysts. They are dark in color due to the accumulation of denuded epithelium.
  • They also have an unpleasant sebum odor.
  • The swelling can ulcerate and become painful (Cock’s peculiar tumor).
  • Some cysts over the scalp may also harden over time (Sebaceous horn).
  • Many may get infected and lead to abscess formation.

Treatment:

  • Excision including skin adjacent to punctum using elliptical incision-dissection method.
  • Incision and avulsion of cyst wall.
  • In the presence of an abscess, an initial treatment with an incision later followed by excision of the cyst

Other options:

Option A: Dermoid cysts present as firm painless subcutaneous nodules and are of 4 types:

  1. Sequestration dermoid - sequestration of epithelium during embryological development
  2. Tubulodermoid - accumulation of secretions from ectodermal tube/duct
  3. Implantation dermoid - implantation of the epidermis due to trauma
  4. Teratomatous dermoid - having all 3 germ layers (ecto, meso, and endoderm)

Option C: Meningiomas are benign tumors arising from the meningothelial cells of the dura. They present with headaches, seizures, or focal neurological deficits.

Option D: Postauricular cutaneous mastoid fistula is a rare complication of chronic otitis media that heals very slowly and needs surgical closure.

questions.text: A female patient presents with a breast abscess. An aspiration was attempted under antibiotic cover which failed to reveal any aspirate. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected

questions.solution:
In a patient with a breast abscess, the next step after a failed aspiration is to attempt aspiration once again under antibiotic cover.

Incision and drainage is not preferred, as it can potentially interfere with breastfeeding, and delicate structures such as ducts, lobules, and tubules may be injured, possibly leading to a non-healing milk fistula.

A breast abscess is a complication of acute mastitis, which is more common in new mothers at the beginning of lactation (lactational mastitis). Non-lactational mastitis is more common in diabetic, immunosuppressed people and people predisposed by duct ectasia and periareolar infections.

Clinical features of a breast abscess include:

  • Fever and malaise
  • Localized pain and tenderness 
  • Redness and swelling of the affected breast
  • Positive fluctuation test.

An ultrasonogram of the affected breast is performed to confirm the abscess, and treatment proceeds as follows:

  • Analgesics, antipyretics, and breast support for pain and fever relief.
  • Aspiration is performed under antibiotic cover, and the pus is cultured. If aspiration proves unsuccessful, it should be reattempted after a few days.
  • Incision and drainage should be considered in cases of:
    • Mastitis unresponsive to antibiotics for 48 hours.
    • Brawny induration.
    • Progressive mastitis with persistent fever

Note:

questions.text: Which nerve is involved in Frey’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
The auriculotemporal nerve (V3 nerve) is involved in Frey's syndrome (gustatory sweating).

Frey’s syndrome is also known as Dupuy syndrome or auriculotemporal syndrome. It commonly develops after parotid surgery. It is caused by an aberrant regeneration of post-ganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibers crossed along the sympathetic pathways to the sweat glands near the parotid region.

Clinical features are due to the result of salivary stimulation (by the smell or taste of food) leading to the sweating and flushing of the periauricular region on the involved side of the face. A starch iodine test is used for diagnosis.

Treatment ranges from antiperspirants (in mild cases) to tympanic neurectomy or botulinum toxin injection (in severe cases). It can be prevented by incorporating careful extracapsular dissection and closure of the superficial musculoaponeurotic layer during parotidectomy.

Other options:

Option A: Facial nerve is the 7th cranial nerve that supplies the muscles of the face, and results in facial paralysis if injured during parotidectomy

Option B: Oculomotor is the 3rd cranial nerve which supplies the extraocular muscles. If injured during ophthalmic surgeries, it results in ocular paralysis and the eye pointing down and out.

Option D: Glossopharyngeal nerve is the 9th cranial nerve and its injury causes loss of taste sensation from the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding deep vein thrombosis (DVT)?

choices.text: Most common clinical presentation is pain and tenderness in calf
Some cases may directly present as pulmonary thromboembolism

questions.solution:
Most cases of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) are unilateral. It is bilateral in only 30% of the individuals.

DVT refers to thrombosis of the deep venous system.

Caused by:

  • Postoperative thrombosis (most common cause)
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)
  • After childbirth
  • Immobility 

Sites:

  • Pelvic veins—common
  • Leg veins—common in femoral and popliteal veins (common on the left side).

Fever is the earliest symptom, which is also most commonly accompanied by pain and tenderness in the calf and thigh (option C).

The following signs could be elicited:

  • Positive Homan's sign: Resistance of calf muscles on passive foreceful dorsiflexion of the foot.
  • Mose's sign: Gentle squeezing of the lower part of the calf from side to side is painful.
  • Neuhof's sign: Thickening and deep tenderness seen on deep palpation of the calf muscles.

Sometimes, the thrombus may get dislodged and present as pulmonary thromboembolism (option D) with features of dyspnoea, tachypnoea, and chest pain.

Clinical features are unreliable for making a definitive diagnosis (option A), and a venous Doppler is the best modality for confirming DVT. It reveals a non-compressible dilated vein. The likelihood of pulmonary embolism can be predicted using modified Wells criteria.

Patients with DVT should be immediately started with subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). If contraindicated due to renal insufficiency or thrombocytopenia-related conditions, they should be started on fondaparinux (indirect factor Xa inhibitor) or bivalirudin (direct thrombin inhibitor). Anticoagulants should be administered for a minimum period of 3 months. Vena cava filters are used in patients with bleeding risks (like hemophilia).

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Venous Thromboembolism

The risk factors for venous thromboembolism (pulmonary embolism and DVT) are as follows:

  • Major trauma like spinal cord injury or fracture of lower limb
  • Surgery like hip or knee replacement
  • Hospitalization for heart failure or atrial fibrillation/flutter within last 3 months
  • Myocardial infarction within last 3 months
  • Previous venous thromboembolism
  • Infections and inflammatory bowel disease
  • Autoimmune diseases:
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (APLA)
    • SLE
  • Inherited thrombophilias:
    • Factor V leiden mutation
    • Deficiency of antithrombin III
    • Deficiency of protein C or protein S
  • Hypercoagulable states:
    • Pregnancy and postpartum period
    • COPD
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Polycythemia vera
    • Malignancies
  • Iatrogenic:
    • OCPs
    • Hormone replacement therapy
    • Chemotherapeutic drugs
    • Insertion of central venous lines
  • Varicose veins
  • Prolonged car or air travel.

Related Pearl: Prophylaxis for DVT

Early ambulation

Acts by activating the calf pump mechanism
Pneumatic compression stocking

Prevents stasis by periodically compressing the calves

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding rectal carcinoma?

choices.text: Hartmann’s operation is done in elderly debilitated patients
Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma
Early morning spurious diarrhoea and tenesmus can occur
Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke’s staging

questions.solution:
Adenocarcinoma is the most common variant of rectal carcinoma.

Colorectal cancer is:

  1. The second most common malignancy globally
  2. The second most common cancer in women
  3. The third most common cancer in men
  4. The fourth most common cause of death due to cancer. 

Symptoms of rectal carcinoma include:

  1. Painless bleeding - earliest and most common
  2. Alteration of bowel habits - change in frequency and consistency of the stool
  3. Tenesmus - unable to pass a motion even when there is the sensation of needing to evacuate the bowel. It is suggestive of a tumor of the lower half of the rectum 
  4. Early morning bloody diarrhea (option C) - passage of blood and mucus in addition to feces. Pain and weight loss are usually late symptoms

Abdominal examination and digital rectal examination are used for the primary evaluation. Rigid sigmoidoscopy is performed to obtain a biopsy. A synchronous tumor (primary tumor with a different origin than the one currently investigated) is excluded by performing a colonoscopy.

Modified Duke’s classification:

A

Growth limited up to the rectal mucosa (option D)

B

B1: Tumor invading muscularis propria, no lymph node invasion.

B2: Tumors invading into or through serosa, no lymph node invasion.

C

C1: The tumour did not exceed the bowel wall, lymph node metastasis.

C2: Tumour exceeded the intestinal wall and lymph node metastasis.

D

Distant metastasis

Surgery is the mainstay of management for rectal carcinoma. Non-operative management is offered to only those patients who have a complete clinical response to neoadjuvant.

The type of surgery depends on multiple factors (size, location, age of the patient, etc). However, the general consensus is:

  1. Early cancer (T1 and a few T2) is locally excised via the transanal approach.
  2. Most rectal cancer is treated by anterior resection and colorectal/coloanal anastomosis.
  3. Low extensive tumors are treated by laparoscopic abdominoperineal resection(APR) and permanent colostomy.
  4. Hartmann’s operation (option A) is preferred in old and frail patients due to poor anal sphincter and postoperative incontinence.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Colorectal Cancer

The risk factors for colorectal cancer are:

  • Dietary:
    • High-animal-fat diet
    • Low-fiber diet
    • Alcohol
  • Hereditary syndromes:
    • FAP
    • HNPCC
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Cholecystectomy: increased right colon cancer due to exposure to bile acids
  • Ureterosigmoidostomy
  • Smoking
  • Acromegaly
  • Pelvic irradiation

questions.text: A gasless abdomen is seen in:
questions.solution:
A gasless abdomen is an X-ray feature that can be seen in acute pancreatitis. Patients with acute pancreatitis can have significant vomiting and diarrhea that may produce a gasless abdomen.

Common causes of gasless abdomen include:

  • High obstruction: gastric outlet obstruction, congenital atresia
  • Small bowel obstruction 
  • Bowel ischemia
  • Ascites
  • Acute pancreatitis
  • Gastroenteritis
  • Large abdominal mass - due to displacement
  • Post-surgery following total colectomy, esophagogastrectomy, gastrectomy, and low anterior resection
  • A paucity of small bowel gas may be a normal finding in some adults

Note: In intussusception, an X-ray shows small bowel obstruction, a mass, and a paucity of gas in the right iliac fossa.

questions.text: Gall stone chemistry most commonly seen amongst the following is:
questions.solution:
The most common gallstone chemistry seen is crystalline cholesterol monohydrate.

Types of gallstones:

  1. Cholesterol stones (75% of gallstones) have >70% cholesterol by weight and are composed of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate. The majority of cholesterol stones have a mixed composition with bile pigments and calcium, in addition to the cholesterol. They are the most common type of gall stones worldwide and in India.
  2. Pigment stones have <20% cholesterol and are dark due to the presence of calcium bilirubinate as the major constituent.
    1. Black pigment stones (20% of gallstones) - are formed due to supersaturation of unconjugated bilirubin (seen in hereditary hemolytic anemia (like sickle cell and hereditary spherocytosis)
    2. Brown pigment stones (5% of gallstones) - formed secondary to infections (like E. coli, and Ascaris lumbricoides)

Note: Pure cholesterol stones are uncommon and account for <10% of all stones.

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient suffering from alcoholic cirrhosis receives a healthy liver from his biological son. What is this type of transplant known as?
questions.solution:
Transplant of an organ/tissue from a son to a parent is an example of an allograft.

An allograft is transplant of cells/tissues/organs from a genetically non-identical donor of the same species.

Isografts are allografts in which cells/tissues/organs are transplanted from a donor to a genetically identical recipient. (monozygotic twins)

Related Pearl: Types of transplants

Type  Definition
Orthotopic

Organ implanted in the same anatomic location in the recipient as it was in the donor. Diseased organ is removed. Eg: heart, lung, liver, intestine
Heterotopic

Organ implanted in a different anatomic location. Diseased organ is left in place. Eg: Kidney, pancreas
Auxiliary transplantation Partial tissue from the donor is used which acts as temporary support for the recipient's injured organ, which remains in place. Eg: left lobe of liver
Autotransplant  Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same person. 
Allotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same species. 
Xenotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs in a different species.
Isograft Transfer of organ or tissue within genetically identical individuals. Eg: Identical twins

questions.text: Esophageal endoscopy of a patient reveals the presence of serpiginous ulcers. This finding indicates:
questions.solution:
The image showing serpiginous ulcers in the otherwise normal mucosa of the distal esophagus is suggestive of cytomegaloviral esophagitis.

Related Pearl: Endoscopic Findings in Esophagitis

 

Conditions Endoscopic findings
Infectious esophagitis Diffuse and involve the proximal esophagus  
HSV esophagitis Vesicles and small punched-out lesions (volcano ulcers)
CMV esophagitis Serpiginous ulcers

Eosinophilic esophagitis Multiple esophageal rings, linear furrows, or white punctate exudates (feline esophagus)
Pill esophagitis Singular and deep at points of luminal narrowing with sparing of the distal esophagus
Candida esophagitis White friable plaques, in advance form - adherent, grey-white pseudomembranes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of revised trauma score (RTS)?
questions.solution:
Pulse rate is NOT a part of revised trauma score.

The Revised Trauma Score is made up of 3 categories: Glasgow Coma Scale, systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate.

The score range is 0–12.

A patient with an RTS score of 12 is labelled delayed, 11 is urgent, and 3–10 is immediate. Those who have an RTS below 3 are declared dead.

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 1 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
3-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score
  • Revised Trauma Score
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)
  • Age

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.
